speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I listened with interest to my hon. friend's remarks and I must say that I totally concur with the support he provides for our supply management system in Canada.
Of course all members of this House are gravely concerned about the potential impact of the GATT negotiations on our dairy, poultry, egg and turkey marketing systems in Canada. We hope that our government and our farm leaders who are involved in the negotiations are successful in getting the Europeans, and particularly the Americans, to recognize that the security of food supply in Canada is a very legitimate concern on the part of Canadian farmers as well as all Canadians.
Nevertheless we may be faced with the prospect that a deal may be reached in GATT that does not provide for the maintenance of supply management, for the maintenance and clarification of article XI, as is the position of this government, as is the wish of literally thousands of farmers across Canada.
I would ask my hon. friend if he would tell us what the position of his party is and what his position is, should an agreement be reached at the GATT that does not provide for the maintenance and clarification of article XI. Is it his recommendation, is it the position of the Liberal party, that the agreement should not be signed by this government?

Government Orders

Mr. Speaker, I was going to thank the hon. member for taking a non-political view on this but I guess I will not.
I will tell him what I would do. I really wish we on this side were in government because we would not have put ourselves in the position this government is in.
If I was a negotiator and I wanted to put forward the best argument I had to support my country, I sure as heck would not go before Canadians and say: "Look, we are going to sign this agreement anyway. But we are fighting as hard as we can on your behalf, but I want you to know, Mr. Bush down there, we are still going to sign this".
I want to ask the hon. member, why is it that George Bush has not said he is going to sign it? Has the head of the European Community said he is not going to sign it? Why is it that our Prime Minister is the only person in the world to come forward and say: "We are going to sign it anyway". What kind of negotiating position is that?

speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: I will remind all members that the discussion is on Bill C-54.

Mr. Speaker, I want to congratulate my colleague, the hon. member for Haldimand-Norfolk who has once again demonstrated a very strong working knowledge of the issues which most affect his constituents. His constituents can be proud of the fact that they have a representative who is such a strong voice for them here in the highest court of the land.
While it is true that supply management is a most complex issue which most affects the producers of Canadian agricultural products, I would like to ask the hon. member this. This issue does not get the attention of people who were born and raised and spend most of their lives in the city. I wonder if the hon. member could explain to those who live in urban Canada that the issues of rural Canada affect them as well.

Mr. Speaker, I thank my hon. friend for those comments. He has hit the issue here. He really has hit the point that all of us on this side of the House, especially those from rural Canada, want to get across. We need to speak to those in the urban centres who are now listening to some newscasts on TV that are telling them that with supply management the prices are much
higher, that farmers are being subsidized. As the minister of fisheries said, they are being subsidized to the tune of $16 billion annually, that governments are paying a lot to their farmers and therefore they are inefficient.
It is not really a hard argument to get across because it is a question of national food security. I ask them in urban centres: Which would they rather have? Would they rather have a country that depends for its food on another country? Canada, because of the closeness of the U.S., would more than likely be dependent on the Americans if we open our borders. The Americans have many advantages over Canadian farmers, not only the cost of production, which I mentioned earlier is 25 per cent cheaper there, mostly because of these government tax increases that we have been seeing over the last few years, but also they have the larger market. They have these large-as our fisheries people say-almost factory ships. They have these huge, huge farms with hundreds of thousands of birds.
Let me tell you, Mr. Speaker, the quality of the meat that comes from these farms I would not even look at, let alone eat. We are talking not only cost, we are talking quality of food. The Canadian quality of food in a supply managed country and the efficiency of those farmers can be found nowhere else in the world.
Which would they rather have? Would they rather have a low quality food which in the beginning may be a little cheaper or would they rather have a country that has a farm sector which can feed itself? It is not too hard an argument to put forward.
I say to Canadians in urban centres that the importance of this question is one of self-sufficiency and national security for Canada. I thank my hon. friend for pointing that out to the House.

Mr. Speaker, I would just ask the member a question, based on his remarks of a few moments ago where he made derogatory statements about the Prime Minister with reference to whether or not Canada might sign the GATT. I would like to remind him that just a few days ago when the NDP was arguing that we should say we will not sign, his colleague, the hon. member for Winnipeg South Centre, who presumably speaks on behalf of his party on external affairs and trade matters, or at least
February 25, 1992

has in the past, suggested that Canada would be crazy not to sign the GATT.
I am wondering how he reconciles his comments about the Prime Minister with the spokesman from his own party who has stated flatly we would be crazy not to sign the GATT at the end of the day.

I have to say to the hon. member that I too was disappointed in the NDP motion. I saw the press release that they put out, and I say this sincerely, that said they were really going to take a hard line on this and stand up for Canadian supply managed farmers. When the motion came forward to the House it never really said anything about whether or not we would sign a deal or not a sign a deal. It had really become watered down. That disappointed me.
In terms of whether or not-
Why didn't you amend it?

Well, Mr. Speaker, we did amend it.
We as a party would never have put ourselves in this position. We as a party would never have signed the free trade deal. Do not forget our leader went down to Washington. He talked to President Bush and let him know exactly where we stand on this issue. We stand fully behind our Canadian farmers. We stand fully behind those Canadians who believe in a national food security policy for Canada. As much as we have tried to convince our friends in the other two parties to take the same stand, they refuse to.

speakerposition: Assistant Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: Before resuming debate, I point out that after the first five hours of debate speeches are limited to a 10-minute maximum, without questions and comments.

Mr. Speaker, it is a pleasure to have the opportunity to make a few comments in regard to the bill that is before us.
Bill C-54, as the title suggests, is really a bill to establish a national farm products council and to authorize the establishment of agencies for farm products.
Government Orders
There are some good sections of this bill. There are also some recommendations in the bill that are going to cause some real difficulties.
The overriding concern I have is that this particular legislation is, at least at this point in time, almost irrelevant in terms of the larger debate that has been before the House and has been discussed at the ongoing negotiations in the General Agreements on Tariffs and Trade. There is not much future in passing this bill if the decision from GATT comes down against the very future of marketing boards and marketing agencies in Canada.
That is why I say that the bill is essentially irrelevant in the context of the larger debate in which we are still immersed.
What really is at stake, when we look at the difficulties that Canadian farmers face, is the very future of marketing board structures in Canada and, I submit, the very future of the Canadian way of life. We have 100,000 Canadian jobs that are dependent upon our well-established system of supply management in Canada: 38,000 dairy, poultry and egg producers, almost 23,000 employees of these farmers and some 36,000 processing jobs that spin-off from these particular industries. That is $4.7 billion that could be lost in farm production if our marketing board systems, which this bill reflects upon, are in fact lost or unravelled, as well as $5.5 billion in processing. When you look at the over-all impact on the Canadian economy, some $100 billion in economic activity is generated by our agricultural community.
I want to go back and put a historical perspective in terms of why this government is between a rock and a hard place on this issue of the future of marketing boards in Canada today. First of all, let us reflect on last Friday when we had over 40,000 dairy, egg and poultry producers from across Canada rally on Parliament Hill in protest of what they conceive to be the possible loss of their livelihoods, the loss of supply management in Canada.
The government tried to spin the line that the 40,000 farmers out on the Hill on Friday had come in support of the government's position on marketing boards, but I want to make perfectly clear that those farmers were angry out there. They did not come in support of the government's position, they came to reinforce and to ensure that the government does not back down on their position with respect to article XI in GATT. If you can call snowballs and eggs a show of support then this

February 25, 1992
Government Orders
government has a rather twisted sense of reality. The farmers are very, very worried that this Prime Minister and this government are about deep-six marketing boards in Canada. They came to make their point perfectly clear to this government that they do not want to see that happen.
How did we get to this position where the future of our agricultural industry is in fact at risk? It is a very serious situation indeed. If you look back to 1987 in some of the opening rounds of the Uruguay round of negotiations at GATT, Canada at that time under this government, this Prime Minister, submitted a proposal to those negotiations, the initial proposal on the table. I read from the script here. It is entitled Proposal by Canada Regarding the Multilateral Trade Negotiations in Agriculture, and it is dated October 20, 1987, from the negotiating group on agriculture.
If I could just read a portion of that text I think the answer to my question becomes perfectly clear. Let me just quote.
Canada proposes the adoption of a comprehensive approach which
would result in the elimination of all subsidies which distort trade and
of all access barriers.
The United States has fingered Canada's marketing boards as being a trade barrier, an access barrier. It has identified the very system of our agricultural industry as being an unfair trade-distorting mechanism. Here is our government acknowledging "all access barriers and distortions of trade will, over a period to be negotiated as an initial phase of this process and consistent with the above goal, a major reduction in all these trade-distorting subsidies, a major improvement in secure and predictable access to be phased in over five years".
It goes on to say: "The use of a single measure"-Mr. Speaker, read my lips: "single measure" means tariff-"which converts all access barriers, administered price systems and trade-distorting subsidies shall be implemented".
What we are talking about here is very simple: We are talking about tariffication of agricultural products into Canada. And if you talk about tariffication, the consequence is ultimately the dismantling of our supply management systems, because supply management using
quotas cannot exist in parallel with the process of tariffication of the industry. It just cannot happen. That is where this government has been duplicitous in its arguments at the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. What it has said over the past week is "we support article XI, we want a strengthened article XI, we support the concept of marketing boards in Canada-oh, yes, but we would also like to see tariffication".
As I said the other day, you cannot have it both ways, and this government has been trying to play two tunes on the same fiddle. We have the Prime Minister talking about the need for support of agricultural marketing boards. We have the Minister for International Trade in a private letter to all his government MPs basically trying to sell the concept of tariffication.
The question I asked last Friday stands: Does this government support marketing boards, or does it support tariffication? You cannot have it both ways.
What is the reason for this whole shemozzle that we now have before us? The reason is very simple: The United States wants to open up our trade barriers to gain access to the Canadian markets to sell their surplus production. And, boy, have they got surplus production. They could have virtually swamped the Canadian market in dairy, poultry and egg produce. That would completely eliminate agricultural life in Canada as we know it today.
The farmers understand that. They know that their future is at risk, they know that their investment is at risk. That is really what is before us today. That is why I say-and I know my time is limited, but if I can just summarize-that this particular bill, Bill C-54, that we have before the House is really irrelevant in the context of this larger debate. Bill C-54 has been presented at this time for the reasons of political optics: The government wants to be made to appear as supporting the concept of agricultural boards and supply management by introducing this piece of legislation. Well, it won't fly. The 40,000 farmers who were on the lawns of Parliament Hill on Friday understood that. Their message was clear: "Don't sell us down the drain with article XI. Don't sell us down the drain by tariffication. Support the future of marketing boards in this country". That is what this government has to do. In terms of the agreement, it may require us saying we are going to ignore those provisions of the agreement. Other countries have done it before. They
February 25, 1992

have ignored the recommendations of GATT. We may very well have to be placed into that position. We cannot sign away the future of agricultural life in Canada today. It is simply unacceptable.

Mr. Speaker, it is my pleasure this morning to make a few remarks about Bill C-54, an act to amend the National Farm Products Marketing Agencies Act and other acts.
Before I get to the bill, I would like to make a few remarks about the tremendous effort made by the producers of Prince Edward Island last Friday in their participation in the great march on Parliament Hill. This had to be the largest but the most orderly march that ever occurred on Parliament Hill.
In Prince Edward Island we have approximately 600 dairy producers. We have a number in the chicken marketing board and the egg marketing board. Out of these total of say 650 farms, fully 200 of these people showed up at their own expense to demonstrate to this government their concern about the possibility of them losing their livelihoods.
On Thursday night after they finished their work in their bams, finished milking their cows and so on, they drove to Charlottetown where they rented two aeroplanes to fly them to Ottawa. They arrived in the middle of the night or very early in the morning, three or four o'clock Friday morning. They caught a few hours of sleep after they checked into their hotel. They showed up on Parliament Hill at 10, 10.30 Friday morning, demonstrated their concern to the government and to government officials and met government officials in the meantime for approximately four to four and a half hours. They then returned to their hotel, flew back in the late evening, arriving in Prince Edward Island at two o'clock in the morning, drove home to their various farms across the island and did their farm work that morning.
This is a tremendous and magnificent demonstration of concern and commitment to the supply marketing system in P.E.I. These farmers knew. They have been looking around for the last number of years, observing what has been happening to their neighbours in agriculture. They are seeing their neighbours who were in the hog industry having a very difficult time partially in regard to the countervailing duty and barriers that our friends to the south continue to put up.
Government Orders
They have noticed their friends who are in the potato industry and seen what they have gone through this last two years since the discovery of PVY-N in the potato crop there. If nothing else, it could scare producers and scare people who live in the rural areas. P.E.I. is basically a rural province. Without the farming and the fishing in Prince Edward Island, we really would have no reason to exist.
There are only four methods, four sources of real wealth in this whole world: farming, fishing, forestry and mining. All wealth derives from these four sources. Prince Edward Island is very fortunate in having two of those sources. They are basic to them to a great degree in farming and fishing and to a lesser extent, but still a very important extent, in forestry. We do not have any mines in Prince Edward Island.
To demonstrate their concern for the future, not only of themselves and their families and their way of life, but to demonstrate their concern for the future of their whole province, we had fully one-third of the producers marching on Parliament Hill to try as a last desperate effort to show this government what is actually going to be happening in Prince Edward Island if it fails in its GATT negotiations.
All is not lost. I do not want to be a harbinger of bad news all the time, but we do have some very powerful friends on the world stage. In this case, it is the Japanese on whom we are going to rely.
The Japanese are very concerned about their import restrictions on rice. They are a very powerful player on the world scene. I cannot see them letting their farmers down with regard to the supply of rice. If the Japanese get a special waiver under GATT to protect their farmers from the importation of rice, there is no reason in the world why this government, the Canadian government, cannot get a similar waiver to protect its farmers in the supply market commodities.
We know that the American farmers are not happy at all with the conclusions that Mr. Dunkel is coming to in order to sign an agreement on agriculture in GATT. The American farmers are not pleased at all. Sixty-some senators in the U.S. Senate have written to the President of the United States. These senators represent rural states. They are urging President Bush not to sign the

February 25, 1992
Government Orders
agreement if it is not changed as far as their producers are concerned.
We know there are a lot of European farmers who are not happy with the Dunkel recommendations, and we know that the Canadian farmers are certainly not in any kind of agreement at all, although it would help to a small extent at least the prairie grain farmers.
What are the chances of these governments signing an agreement, knowing very well that farmers in various countries, Canada, the United States, Japan and Europe are not at all happy. I really cannot see politicians overruling or overriding the concerns of their farmers.
It is strange that we are debating Bill C-54 here today. It is a bill that, if the government fails in protecting article XI and in strengthening article XI, will only be of use to farmers who are not in the supply marketing system. This bill that we are amending is called the National Farm Products Marketing Act.
This is the act that the Liberal government put through in 1970-72 with Senator Bud Olson and the friend of marketing boards whom all farmers know, Eugene Whelan. They fought to put that act through in those days. This is legislation under which they formed the dairy marketing board, the chicken marketing board, the turkey marketing board and so on.
This is the legislation they were created under. If the government fails and our supply marketing system goes to tariffication, the only people who are going to benefit by this act at all are those who are not in the supply marketing system.
The horticultural industry or the beef producers will be able to form agencies in order to collect check-offs which are funds that they will be using to promote and market their products. They will be the only farm groups able to use this particular legislation.
It is a very unusual thing. I do not know why the government chose to use this particular act to bring in this ability. I know this is going to be of great benefit to people in the horticultural industry, especially those who spend a lot of money promoting their products. We have a very short growing season here and they put great effort into promoting products such as strawberries. We
spend the rest of the year importing strawberries from the rest of the world, especially the United States. Now, we will be able to check off strawberries and other horticultural products coming into Canada which will be to the benefit of our farmers in this regard.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to have a few moments to speak on Bill C-54. As my colleague from Egmont said, this bill only has limited use and really only applies to certain sectors of the agricultural community. The previous speaker from the New Democratic Party mentioned that this bill is more political optics. It is another diversionary bill from the Government of Canada.
I want to speak to this bill as an urban member. So often in agricultural issues members, especially urban members, do not fully comprehend the relationship of the needs of the rural community to our needs in an urban centre.
The relationship became very apparent to me about a year ago when I was visiting Moscow. While I was there speaking at an environmental summit I had the occasion to visit various parts of the city. I got up early in the morning to make these visits and day after day I saw people lining up at seven o'clock in the morning with brown cloth sacks waiting to get into the local food market. When I saw these lines I naturally thought: "Well, there must be some kind of a special on in these particular stores". However, upon further research I saw that the reason these people were lining up at seven o'clock in the morning was because there was just not enough supply. If they did not get there early in the morning they might not have any food for the day.
I went into a few of these stores and upon examining the situation even more closely I could see that it was not just that the quantity was so little but that the quality of the food was so poor. It is absolutely beyond one's imagination. You have to have been there and seen it to believe it. The way people in Moscow treasure their food supply is something that we in this country have no conception of.
When I returned I did my grocery shopping in the local Knob Hill Farms or Loblaws or some of the other stores in the Danforth area and I thought back to the experience I had in Moscow and Latvia, where most of the shelves were absolutely bare.
February 25, 1992

We in this country have no real appreciation for security of food supply. We have no idea of the importance of the contribution the farming community of this country makes toward our quality of life. You really must be without or see people living without in order to fully appreciate it.
We saw a situation last week when close to 40,000 farmers visited this city to try to communicate a message of concern. They were not just sending that message of concern for their own farms. They were sending a message of concern for all people in this country. We in this Chamber have to get our heads around this issue. We have to wake up and make sure that people in this country understand that the link between the rural economy and the urban economy is an inextricable one. As the rural economy goes so goes our urban economy. I have been saying in this House that the strength of this nation is proportional to our food supply.
We are a nation whose strength has always been measured by our ability not only to feed ourselves but feed other regions of the planet. We have one of the most progressive food supply programs anywhere in the world.
Yesterday, I referred to a paper written by my colleague from Lambton-Middlesex, Compare the Share. Today I would like to refer members to a paper written by a member from the government side, the member for Souris-Moose Mountain. In January 1992 he presented a paper called: Food: A Priority. It is a fabulous document. One of the national journalists in The Toronto Star, Carol Goar, covered this paper in late January. I refer it to everyone in this House.
What we are talking about here today in this bill is bringing attention not only to all members of this House but to all Canadians that our farming communities and our agricultural communities need help right now. They need to know that we, as national politicians, are behind them. We are behind them because that security of supply, that quality of supply, is something that has always been the envy of the world. The government over the past few years has tended to dismantle things, tended to retreat from governance rather than charging ahead.
Government Orders
Rather than leading this government tends to wait and see, to hive off, to decentralize.
I am so nervous. With the budget coming out today, with the constitutional document before us, with this tremendous problem we are having with the most precious resource we have in this country, our agricultural community is being shaken to the core. I am so nervous that if this government continues on its current strategy of devolution of powers and dismantling our farmers may be caught in the cross-fire.
The Prime Minister said last week that he would do his best to maintain the marketing boards of this country. I hope, not only for rural Canada but for all of Canada and also for the world, that he is able to achieve that because the greatest strength this country has is not only the ability to feed ourselves but to feed those who are most disadvantaged in the rest of the world.

Mr. Speaker, I appreciate the opportunity to speak on Bill C-54, an act to amend the Farm Products Marketing Agencies Act and other acts in consequence thereof.
Grain growers, poultry producers, dairy farmers are all fighting together. The government has moved away from the position it took on GATT originally but is also trying to bolster the position it claims to have now.
I want to concentrate on one industry and a letter dated February 12, 1992 on the impact of tariffication on Canadian chicken producers. What they argue could come about is really devastating. The Canadian Chicken Marketing Agency has analysed the impact of the Dun-kel proposals on Canadian producers. The conclusion of the CCMA analysis is that within three years, 86 per cent of Canadian producers would be out of business and only 330 out of Canada's 2,411 producers would remain. Within two years production of chicken would have ceased in Atlantic Canada. It is unlikely that many processing plants would survive the first several years. Within six years the industry would have all but disappeared, only 39 producers would be left.
I and many Canadians are concerned, especially the
40,000	farmers and agriculture producers who were here last week, about Canada's food self-sufficiency if the government fails to protect our marketing boards and fails to strengthen or keep the provisions of article XI of the GATT

February 25, 1992
Government Orders
They do not trust this government. It is obvious they do not trust this government to protect the needs of the Canadian people and the workers involved with producing our agricultural foods across Canada.
It is much broader than that. We must alert the Canadian people that it is much broader than that. Where I come from the people in our transportation industry, in the railway industry depend very heavily on the transportation of grain across Canada. If we start to lose those markets it will affect everyone, every Canadian. Every Canadian must stand up to protect the very efficient system we have at the present time.
There is another area of concern which we have not identified. If we start to get into the really competitive market in which things begin to concentrate in one area and we start to try to be efficient and produce on a large scale, if we have large-scale processing of agricultural goods, such as the poultry industry or the turkey industry, and they start to concentrate in one area our environment is going to be very heavily affected because we are going to have a concentration of these large groups of processing plants trying to be efficient. We have a very efficient area spread across various parts of Canada. It is important to identify the environmental aspects of what we may be looking at here.
These are the kinds of discussions that took place earlier with regard to free trade. It shows very clearly that when we were dealing with the Americans regarding the free trade agreement we should have been looking at each sector of our economy, and at how to trade and be self-sufficient in our own country. We have not done that. We are starting to feel the ramifications of a trade agreement that does not recognize the self-sufficiency of our own country. If this is to proceed we will allow the basic fundamental agricultural programs essential to self-sufficiency in Canada to go down the drain. I do not think the Canadian people are ready to accept that. Our critic for agriculture has worked extensively with this. He has brought delegations to our caucus and talked it over. We have discussed it with the turkey producers, the grain producers, the poultry producers and the egg marketing boards. The people who protested in front of this building simply do not trust the Mulroney government to protect the agricultural base in this country.
Unless we as the opposition on this side of the House and the people of Canada start to stand up and really put the pressure on this government to bring about the protection that is required, I think we will be faced with the very dim results of not being able to sustain our own agricultural base in our own country.
I do not think there is a country anywhere in the world that would allow its agricultural base and its very basic foods that average Canadian people accept every day to be delivered from another country.
I know I am not prepared as a member of Parliament. I get faxes coming from grain producers in my part of southeastern British Columbia and from the dairy and poultry industries. They are small industries but are very important to every part of our country. We must protect these boards. If we do not we are going find, as the chicken industry has indicated, that the industry will have all but disappeared within six years.
That is what we are faced with. If this government does not get away from its idea of trying to support tariffication, and at the same time telling the marketing boards and the people involved that it is there to fight for their rights, I do not think we are going to get the results we are hoping for.
I would urge all Canadians to get on the wire, contact this government and tell it that we are not going to accept anything but a strengthening of Article XI of the GATT.

Mr. Speaker, it is a pleasure to have the opportunity to speak today, following probably the biggest rally this nation has ever known last Friday on the lawn of Parliament Hill.
If you had the opportunity as I had over the weekend to go back and mingle with a few practising farmers who spend their time in the stable regularly, you would find there is great agonizing going on out there. There is real pain and real hurt in the dairy industry.
We speak of the dairy industry in particular, but it would equally apply of course to the poultry industry. Farmers can always be so practical in their examples of things that really hit home. I heard one poultry farmer say that when an American chicken arrives at the border to come into Canada, remember it has not been fed on Canadian grain. That is quite a message. They do not need any Canadian grain. They have enough grain in the
February 25, 1992

United States to feed the chickens. How are we supposed to have any money to buy the chickens?
I do not think most people realize that. They are not just talking about bringing a few articles across the border and putting a tariff on them. If they had been fed Canadian grain, that is one thing. But would you expect that American chicken to ever be fed on Canadian grain? You can see the ramifications that would have for the grain distributors, the grain dealers and everyone else down through the cycle. That is the kind of practical experience I have had in my association with these dairy farmers as they try to relate where their industry would now go with this new thinking.
We must remember too that we are still recognized as northern people. This city we are in right now has the coldest average climate I think of any capital in the world. We must not forget that. Are we going to throw our markets open to free market forces when that is one thing we have to contend with? We cannot do much about that but it has a great impact on the livelihood. Do we think we can become competitive by just throwing our basic food supplies open to market forces and going toe to toe with the Americans? If we take the example of the dairy industry, all you have to do is go down into North and South Carolina and a little bit farther south and look at the herds of dairy cattle they have there. They do not have bams, they have milking parlours. They are very, very sophisticated. They milk three times a day. The cow is just a machine they push feed through.
The farmer in Grenville County, a few miles away, may have an excellent herd of 60 or 70 cows and make a decent living. Perhaps he is able to pay for his tractor, make his payments at the bank, meet the guy who comes around from the Farm Credit Corporation and keep him happy. How can he compete with what you see going on down south in the Carolinas with those huge herds? Bams are not a great problem down there. They have some protection for their cattle, naturally, but most of the cattle stay outside. They can afford to do that because they do not have the inclement weather we have up here. Anyone who can describe how they can carry on an industry up here and compete with that I think should go out and talk to some farmers. They will explain it in a sensible way as they are so capable of doing.
Government Orders
I can remember those years before we had a managed marketing system. I can remember when you had 13 or 14 cows and you managed because you sold your milk to the cheese factory down the road and you had a regular pay cheque coming in. No farmer would admit that is where we should be today. They are entrepreneurs. They will move with the times. They are willing to go out and borrow money and expand their operations, and a lot of them did. They borrowed more because they were told this was the way to go. They borrowed from the banks and any other source they could get relief from, and now they find themselves in a big dilemma.
Some would accuse the farmer of always whining. That is not the real experience. Go out and talk to these people. They are going through a lot of agony right now. In most cases they are operating with borrowed money. They thought they were doing the right thing.
The farmers appreciated the changes. There is no question about that. The farmer is no different than any other businessman. In order for him to survive he realized he had to go out and acquire three, four or five former farms and he was willing to do that. When you expand your acreage like that a lot of other things have to happen. If you are going to have a viable and competitive operation, everything else along the line has to be expanded. They borrowed lots of money and bought bigger equipment, bigger tractors and advanced farm machinery. They were willing to do that, but with the uncertainty that is out there today they wonder if they should have bothered. They are probably thinking they should not have bothered.
Farmers like to think their contribution is recognized in this country, but then you see 30,000 to 40,000 assembled out here, leaving their farms, getting on buses all day and all night, spending two hours out here and the Prime Minister of this country does not even have the decency to show up. For the Prime Minister to not even make an appearance on the Hill hurt the farmers and it hurt them terribly. I can tell you farmers have long memories. Maybe while they are milking those cows or spending time in their bams they will have a little more time for this kind of practical remembrance. They will remember that, I can guarantee you, ladies and gentlemen. That will not be forgotten.

February 25, 1992
Government Orders
The farmers are not finished yet. This was just an initial response to their concern about their industry. Last Friday it was announced that further demonstrations are being planned. I hope that at some point the Prime Minister will come out of hiding and go and meet those people who are out there trying to make a contribution to our Canadian way of life. The big problem with the dairy industry prior to the milk marketing board was the great inconsistencies. The amount of product put out on the market was up and down. If you are going to go out and invest a lot of money in something, you cannot live with that kind of uncertainty. The marketing board was endeavouring to provide some kind of consistency. The banks would not lend you any money to start with if they could not have some assurance you were going to be able to pay it back. The way to pay it back is to guarantee there will be some consistency. The price of the product then was based on a formula and this changed in what we called the marketing system. They took into account the cost of the man's production, the cost of his seed, the cost of his fertilizer, and all the other factors that you would put into that formula. They saw there had to be a margin of profit, of course, and they arrived at a figure. How much is this man then entitled to put out on the market?
With that kind of thinking behind it, he could be assured that he was going to get a pay cheque. He knew roughly how much it was going to be, and he was going to be able to meet his commitments.
Farmers are just asking to have that system recognized. Could you imagine if the marketing boards were prevalent in the United States? George Bush is going out and promoting this movement away from marketing boards. The farmers in the States-and they were out here last Friday too in great numbers-would love to have the system we have here. But because of political reasons Mr. Bush cannot visualize giving them this system. It is an election year in the United States. Canadian dairy and poultry farmers are paying the price for a weak voice on the part of this Canadian industry down in the United States.
I think the Canadian farmers deserve a better hearing than that. I think the Prime Minister should at least stand up and apologize to Canadian farmers for not being present at the biggest rally we have ever witnessed. He should tell them when he is going to meet with Canadian farmers in this country, because they deserve better treatment than that, and they will remember.

speakeroldname: Mr. Francis G. LeBIanc (Cape Breton Highlands - Canso):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to participate in this debate on Bill C-54 and to have the opportunity to say a few words on the crisis facing our Canadian farmers, particularly those farmers who live in eastern Canada.
The debate today concerns the amendments to the Farm Products Marketing Agencies Act, in order to implement the enabling legislation for a check-off for imports into Canada. That is the immediate purpose of the legislation. But the legislation will become irrelevant to many in Canada if our agriculture industry is decimated. Certainly that is the feeling among many farmers, particularly those who operate under supply management, if the current proposals that are being debated at the GATT are allowed to go through and the strengthened article XI which the Canadian agricultural industry has been urging this government to defend and which the Liberal party implemented to its great credit some 20 years ago is allowed to go by the wayside.
I have farmers in my constituency. I have dairy farmers, poultry farmers, turkey farmers and mixed farmers in my constituency, and I can tell you they are very worried.
They are very worried that the value of their farms will plummet, their life savings will disappear, and they will find themselves forced to abandon their farms. We will find, in Atlantic Canada as well as in other parts of Canada, the lands which are now productively tilled, which not only enhance our food security but our environment, allowed to grow covered with weeds and deteriorate. As a consequence, in Atlantic Canada we will lose our farms and our farmers, that segment of the population which is not only of large economic value to Canada but of large social and cultural value and is part of our security as a country. The issue is bigger than simply the amendments to the Farm Products Marketing Agencies Act.
February 25, 1992

I want to say a few words on behalf of our supply managed fanners, particularly the ones in my constituency. I had an opportunity just a week ago to speak with a couple who have been farming in the region of Mabou in Inverness County. They are dairy farmers who purchased a farm some eight years ago. They are young, articulate spokespersons for the farm industry and honest, hardworking citizens of the community. They are making that dairy farm work. It is an excellent operation, very efficient. They have worked on that farm for the last 18 months without a holiday. They actually came to the rally last week. That was the first opportunity they had to leave the farm. They took the train to Ottawa to participate in the rally and show their concern on behalf of dairy farmers in Nova Scotia about the consequences if supply management is allowed to be negotiated away in the GATT negotiations.
They are very distrustful of this government. They do not believe this government's protestations that it supports supply management. They see double talk and duplicity in the words of the Minister of Agriculture, the Minister for International Trade and the Prime Minister when they talk about supporting supply management. They see that the government's words are hollow and that it is unwilling to stand up for the farmers and other Canadians whose interests are being compromised in international bodies.
We have a government that is unwilling to go toe to toe with other governments, particularly the Government of the United States, and defend our interests. It is necessary that the government be willing to take measures that will hurt the Government of the United States and hurt the interests of the United States to demonstrate that we defend our own interests. That is what this government has been unwilling to do for a whole series of interests, not only the free trade agreement and the interests that have been attacked since the free trade agreement was put in place.
It has also shown how spineless it is with respect to defending Canadian sovereignty beyond the 200-mile limit in the nose and tail of the Grand Banks where we have watched the plundering of fish stocks by the Spanish and the Portuguese fleets for five years. This government continues to say: "Well, we are negotiating.
Government Orders
We are exercising diplomacy. We are having a public relations campaign". All the while our fish stocks are being plundered.

Unilateral declaration of that area as a management zone for Canadians.

There is basis in international law. I am sure that is what we will have to do eventually. However, the problem is that we will be too late. There will be no fish left.
In any case, I am deviating from the point at hand which is the agricultural sector. What is really affecting farmers at the moment is what is taking place in those GATT negotiations.
The member for South Shore knows full well that if article XI is allowed to disappear, if we replace the supply management system the Liberal Party put in place with a system of tariffication all the farmers in his part of Nova Scotia will be destroyed in a very short while.
The farms will disappear, and I am sure he will bear the consequences of that electorally. Worse than that, farmers will see the values they have built up over generations decimated at the hands of international negotiations and a government unwilling to defend its interests when push comes to shove.
Push has come to shove. Push is coming to shove at the GATT negotiations with the Americans, and with the Spanish and the Portuguese fleets off the 200-mile limit in the nose and tail of the Grand Banks. It is time that this government defend our interests on the world stage, which is what it has been consistently unwilling to do.
We are finding our sovereignty eroded in so many vital areas that touch our economic interest. That is the point of this debate. That is what is at issue here, far beyond the immediate question of this legislation which on the face of it is necessary legislation because it at least

February 25, 1992
Government Orders
provides the enabling legislation to allow this government to take some steps in defence of our agricultural sector.
It will be too little too late if we lose article XI at the GATT.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to be able to speak to this bill today. This bill causes me some concern and I know it causes concern to the farming community across this country.
Today there is a tremendous farm crisis in Canada. It is not only in western Canada, where I come from, but right across this nation.
Certainly the one area of farming that has been truly successful in the past few years has been marketing boards and those areas under supply management. They have taken farm products, dairy, milk or whatever, and structured an economy around them so producers in that area know they will have a solid income and that they will be able to survive and progress as a farm family.
This whole area of supply management is now coming under review. It is in question and in jeopardy of being lost forever. I really wish that the government, instead of focusing on this particular bill today which is not going to help marketing boards in the end, would focus its attention on other areas.
This bill will provide a check-off or an opportunity to pick farmers' pockets in a fashion that is completely unnecessary.
This government should be focusing some attention on the area of farm finance and farm debt. The areas of farming really in desperate straits are those farmers who have incurred huge debts, are paying huge interest rates, have a shortfall of income and are struggling.
This is the government that, back in 1989, introduced its Growing Together paper with a huge fanfare. As a result of that a number of task forces were set up to look at a whole host of areas including farm debt and farm finance.
There can be nothing more important than managing farm finances. These days you borrow a lot of money. It is nothing to have a $200,000 or $250,000 debt. That is not unusual. If a farmer borrows sums of money of that magnitude at 10 or 12 per cent, which happened in the
1970s, and suddenly a few years later is faced with 18, 20, 21 and 22 per cent and higher interest rates, it is very hard to manage that operation. Many farmers have found themselves with problems not because they mismanaged their farms but because of high interest rates and low prices. The complement to farm finance is farm income.
This government has failed to bring in any substantial legislation to deal with farm finances. It has thrown out money here and there in a haphazard fashion. In particular the grain sector of agriculture has really suffered.
The government is providing lip service to supporting supply management. In actual fact I believe-and most farmers believe it as well-the government is simply going to say: "Look, we did our best. We have tried for you but we have to let supply management go". There will go the prize. The most successful aspect of agriculture under supply management will be a thing of the past. It will disappear.
Every region of the country in rural areas depends on a particular source of the economy, a primary source of the economy. In areas where supply management and farming are factors it is a tragedy to think of losing those farms. If we look at areas of Quebec and Ontario where supply management is very prominent, there are literally tens of thousands, hundreds of thousands of people who will be affected. In rural areas of Quebec there are regions that depend on supply management. When these farmers disappear that whole region-and many regions are suffering economically now-is going to be extremely depressed.
This government, although it undoubtedly has to be aware of it and I know there are many members from Quebec who very concerned about it, seems to be unwilling. In fact the government seems to have been steered in that general direction over the last number of years to the point of saying: "I am sorry, we have done what we could".
Unless there is a commitment to supply management, unless that commitment is strong and is going to maintain itself, there is going to be devastation in many regions of this country. To see the supply managed sector disappear is a heart break for all farmers.
February 25, 1992

The other aspect of this bill and this attitude of the government toward supply management and agriculture in general has been to split the farm community. The farm community is a diverse lot, to begin with. These are independent people who have pride in their farm, pride in their land, and are individuals. That is to be applauded. When we talk to various agricultural groups we find many different positions depending on which group we speak with. Western Canadian wheat growers certainly have a different position from that of National Farmers Union.
What is more fundamental is that a split is now being perpetrated, I would suggest, by this government between the supply managed sector and the grain sector. We had this GATT proposal sitting in front of us which tells the grain producers that there will be lower subsidies in European and American grain. Hopefully this will mean a somewhat higher price in grain. On the other hand it is saying we have to do that at the expense of the supply manage sector. A grain producer on the prairies who is in debt up to his eyeballs and is looking for anything to survive is in some ways faced with an option he cannot refuse. The effect has been to split the two groups, and that is a tragedy because farm families are all in the same boat. They simply want to have their land and produce their product whatever it might be, whether it is grain or cattle or poultry or dairy. They want to have an income and they simply want to live their lives. These people contribute a tremendous amount to the economy.
The sad part is that in rural regions across this country, whether we are talking about farming or looking at fishing communities in Atlantic Canada, there is a tremendous amount of financial and emotional stress. Until the government, until we as a Parliament say to the people of this country that we think rural Canada is important and that we are going to pay special attention to rural Canada, this problem is going to continue. Unfortunately over the last 40 years we have had successive governments with an urbanization mentality and much of the legislation passed has been passed without the consideration of rural Canada.
I find it very frustrating and sad that we seem to go on ad nauseam ignoring rural Canada. We pay lip service to it. We talk in glowing terms of living on the farm, the rural way of life and so on. Yet we do very little about it.
Government Orders
Instead of debating bills such as this one which is simply going to hurt supply management, or is certainly not going to help it, we should be focusing our attention on areas in rural Canada that will help rural Canadians to maintain a viable rural infrastructure for all of rural Canada and focusing a commitment on those farm families and on those rural communities. It is an issue that is long overdue. It needs attention. It is about time that we in this Parliament started paying attention to some of the needs of rural Canada because if we do not do it and if we do not do it soon there will be nothing left to say.

subtopic: CANADA-FINLAND INCOME TAX CONVENTION ACT, 1991 MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to put a few comments about the bill on the record.
This bill seeks to implement tax conventions between Canada and Finland, Canada and the Czech and Slovak Federal Republic and Canada and the United Mexican States, and a convention between Canada and the United Mexican States for the exchange of tax related information.
Tax treaties promote international trade and investment. They provide stability for investors by offering certainty regarding the method and rates of taxation of income flowing between countries. Ihx treaties also seek to alleviate double taxation of income from international transactions.
The three tax treaties under review follow the general pattern of treaties previously approved by Parliament. Indeed Canada has over 50 some treaties in existence at the present time all based on an OECD model. Important administrative benefits are provided for taxpayers. The requirement to pay tax on business profits in the country where the profits originated is eliminated unless the taxpayers have a permanent establishment in that country.
As well, treaties provide a mechanism to settle various problems encountered by taxpayers in the interpretation and application of treaties. One of the most important aspects of tax treaties is the alleviation of double taxation where the same income is taxed in the hands of the same person by two different countries. Tax treaties eliminate double taxation in these situations by either providing
one of the states with the exclusive right to tax or by ensuring that taxes paid in one state can be used to offset taxes payable in the other state.
I would now like to indicate briefly the main elements of the three tax treaties currently before the House. I will deal with the fourth item, the exchange of information, later on in my remarks. These treaties provide generally that dividends may be taxed in the source country at a maximum rate of 15 per cent. A 10 per cent rate will apply to dividends paid to a company that holds an equity interest of at least 10 per cent, except that it is 25 per cent in the case of Mexico, of the voting power in the company paying the dividends.
In the case of interest paid by a resident of one country to a resident of the other country, a general rate of 10 per cent, except that it is 15 in the case of Mexico, will apply. There are however a number of exceptions which I discussed in my remarks during second reading.
With respect to royalties the conventions provide for a general rate of 10 per cent, 15 per cent in the case of Mexico, in the source country. Copyright royalties from cultural or artistic works are generally exempt from withholding tax under the three treaties if the recipient pays tax on the royalties.
Some of the other matters dealt with in these tax treaties include capital gains, discriminatory treatment of foreign nationals and pensions. The treaty provisions dealing with capital gains reflect the standard Canadian position enabling the source country to tax gains arising on the sale of real property, business assets and shares in real estate companies. Under the treaties discrimination on the basis of nationality is prohibited, thereby ensuring nationals of a country equal treatment with nationals of the other country in the same circumstances. However, this does not prevent a country from providing fiscal incentives, for example the small business deduction, to resident taxpayers.
I would also like to point out that Canada has preserved its right to tax pensions and annuities paid to residents of the three countries involved in these treaties.
The final item I want to discuss is the exchange of information convention with Mexico. It was signed before the signature of the comprehensive double taxation convention I have just described and complements the comprehensive treaty. The exchange of information
February 25, 1992

convention will assist the revenue authorities in combating tax evasion.
I might say that the convention with Mexico is the result of 15 years of negotiations. The Mexicans had declined to have tax treaties before that and Canada is one of the first countries to achieve such a thing. I should also say for the record that notwithstanding the fact that many of my hon. colleagues from the NDP availed themselves of the second reading to get up and have a debate on Canada-U.S.-Mexico or North American trade, which may well be fair ball if that is their perspective.
I want to point out for the benefit of this House that this tax treaty with Mexico has absolutely nothing to do with trade negotiations between Canada, Mexico and the United States or Canada and any other country. This is a straightforward procedure, one that is common between countries and one in which Canada already has 50 treaties with other countries of the world.
Let me conclude by saying that these tax conventions provide equitable solutions to the various problems of double taxation existing between Canada and these countries. The three countries which have signed these agreements all hope to implement the conventions as soon as possible. Consequently I commend this bill to the most favourable consideration of this House.

speakeroldname: Mr. Peter Milliken (Kingston and the Islands):
subtopic: CANADA-FINLAND INCOME TAX CONVENTION ACT, 1991 MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I had the privilege like the hon. member of rising to speak at second reading of this bill. I rose on behalf of my colleague, the learned member for Windsor West. He was unable to be present at the time of second reading debate and asked me to assist him by making a brief submission to the House in respect of this bill. I am pleased to do so again at third reading.
As I indicated at the time of second reading, we were concerned that the bill should go before a committee so that a committee could review in detail the negotiated tax treaties between the three countries involved. I believe that the committee has now completed that work, that a report has been submitted to the House, and that it has recommended the bill without amendment. Apparently the committee was satisfied that the bill
Government Orders
complied in all respects with the usual form of these kinds of treaties and accordingly recommended them to the House for consideration.
Generally tax treaties between Canada and other countries are beneficial and avoid the incidence of double taxation on income earned by Canadians who reside in those countries or who carry on business there. In that respect we think this is a very positive step.
I want to say that the parliamentary secretary in his remarks made comments about the Mexican free trade deal and the fact that it had been dragged into the debate by the New Democratic Party during the debate at second reading. Frankly I think it was a move by the NDP to kill time. There is not really much that is controversial in this particular bill. I agree the tax treaty with Mexico has nothing to do with any free trade agreement that the government might negotiate with that country.
I suspect members of the New Democratic Party were reflecting a view which we share, that this government is not a good negotiator. Any of the negotiations it carries on are liable to result in a disaster for Canada. We have had lots of evidence of that. I suspect that is why they have raised the issue on this particular bill. I must say I share their concern fully. We have expressed the concern on many occasions. I expressed it again earlier this morning in a speech on another bill, and I am not going to repeat my remarks which I know Your Honour felt were irrelevant to that particular bill.
Having said all that, I want to say that we are delighted the committee has reviewed this bill. I am not an expert in this field and I defer to others who are more knowledgeable about the technicalities of tax treaties, as very complicated as they are.
We are prepared to allow the bill to pass at this stage. I am pleased to give our support to it in light of all the things that have transpired to date.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, these days with all the news of taxation concerns, finances, and all the bad news that is coming out, it is nice once in a while to have some good news. I would like to start my remarks by complimenting a particular individual who resides in the city of Moose Jaw.

February 25, 1992
Government Orders
Every year we have the Saskatchewan Telemiracle. Local radio station CHAB does its own 36-hour Telemiracle. Last week one of the announcers, Mike Hardy, did a 36-hour telethon and raised over $7,200 for the people of Saskatchewan. As Mike Hardy would say, that is good news.
With respect to some bad news, I like most Canadians have some real concerns about what this government is doing with respect to taxation and budgetary matters. There is some real concern with respect to the directions this government has taken over the last number of years in its financial affairs. Certainly as a party, the New Democrats have gone on record, and very forcefully, that we are opposed to legislation such as the goods and services tax which we see as an unfair and regressive tax and have called for its elimination.
Often we get the comment that it is very fine for the New Democrats to call for the elimination of the GST, but what would you do in the alternative? Where are you going to raise the funds and what are you going to do?
We have put forth a lot of alternatives and certainly one of our economic critics from Winnipeg has done an awful lot of work leading the party in developing alternatives. The member for Essex-Windsor has also done similar work. Over the last few years, we have developed a real economic alternative. It had originally been suggested that the GST would cause a 1.25 per cent increase in consumer prices. In fact consumer prices have risen by over 2.6 per cent. Retail sales have declined by 5.3 per cent in volume. Exports have declined by 2.9 per cent and imports have increased by 5 per cent.
There has been an increase in the number of people cross-border shopping and I suggest it is for legitimate reasons in a sense that there are a lot of economic factors.

subtopic: CANADA-FINLAND INCOME TAX CONVENTION ACT, 1991 MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
I do not think the New Democratic Party has to apologize to the hon. member or anyone else for the approach we have taken in this country with taxation. This party has been very effective and has put forth all kinds of alternatives and suggestions as to how this government can improve the financial state of most Canadians in this country.
There are provinces in this country that have New Democratic governments in place. Saskatchewan's government is being responsible and putting forth budgetary restraints contrary to the last government which was a Tory government. Supposedly the Tories have a history of being financial experts and economic managers but they have done a tremendous job of creating problems in Saskatchewan and are on the way to affecting this entire country.
The hon. member's comments are totally unjustified and I think made in a purely partisan manner which does not benefit this House or anybody in this country. I am very disappointed with those comments.
I just want to point out, with respect to the goods and services tax and other regressive taxes in this country, the New Democrats have put forth many, many alternatives. We have called for changes in corporate tax rates which are essential if the average Canadian is going to survive in this country. According to the Public Accounts of Canada, budgetary revenue from corporations has decreased from 20.1 per cent in the early 1960s to 16 per cent in the 1970s. It is down to about 9 per cent today.
If we are going to have fair taxation in this country it is important, in developing legislation, that we focus on fair taxation for corporations. It is something we have not done, it is something we have been moving away from. I would suggest that an initial move should be to make changes to corporate tax rates.
We would also suggest that there should be a change to progressive tax rates in this country. Changes to the Income Thx Act could result in a situation in which there is no difference between the rate paid by those who earn $50,000 a year and those who earn $250,000 a year. The middle class is being taxed the same as the upper class, and that is not fair, that is not just. Our income tax system must be made more progressive, and those at the
February 25, 1992

top of the income scale must be asked to contribute more than they are now. That is only fair.
The Reform Party recently talked about a flat tax, which is a most preposterous notion. Certainly the Reform Party focuses on simplicity and that is a proposition that does not bear scrutiny. With a flat tax, under the proposal they have made, the only people to pay higher taxes would be the poor and those with low incomes. That is certainly going in the opposite direction of fair and proper taxation.
The government argues that higher income taxes drive people to move to the U.S. This may be true of a few people for whom Canada is nothing more than a place to make money. However, for the majority of Canadians, professional or otherwise, Canada will continue to be the country of their choice, particularly if their taxes are used to build a society that benefits all Canadians and not just a few.
Those are alternatives. We need to implement a green tax in this country. The environment in this country and world-wide is in dire straits. As a result, such a direction is extremely important if this country is to progress and develop.
The approach the New Democrats have taken in this country toward taxation has been both reasoned and logical, and it is certainly an approach that will benefit all people.
I want to make one more comment relating to regional taxation. There has been a lack of interest or a lack of direction in taxation in this country with respect to the regions of this country. If we are to maintain regional development we must have a new approach to taxation.
The best example is Atlantic Canada. Billions and billions and billions of dollars have been pumped into that area. Are they any less dependent? No, they are not. In fact they are more dependent. About 15 years ago I talked to one official who got quite discouraged with Ottawa politics. He said he had a deputy minister responsible for DREE who indicated that he wished we could simply take all the maritimes and turn it into a park so we could all go visit there once a year. That is very well for someone outside that region of the country.

speechtext: Mr. Speaker, I appreciate the opportunity to make these remarks today. I think these are very important issues for all Canadians and should be raised on a constant and continuing basis.

subtopic: CANADA-FINLAND INCOME TAX CONVENTION ACT, 1991 MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I will try to direct my comments to the bill. The problem we have here is that we would like to see agreements reached under which Canadians would receive fair taxation. This bill identifies Finland and Mexico. The problem I and my party have, especially our trade critic, is that the free trade agreement and the negotiations taking place with Mexico have not even been presented before this House. Yet, here we have a bill being presented with regard to taxation with Mexico. It could have serious ramifications for the trade talks going on with the Mexican government.
That bothers me a great deal. Our member for Esquimalt-Juan de Fuca on numerous occasions has urged this government to bring forward the proposals it is discussing and trying to bring about in the discussions with Mexico. Yet, we have a bill being introduced by the government to reach a tax agreement with Mexico. Is it not fair ball that we should know about the discussions taking place with regard to the free trade discussions with Mexico? Should we not know about the discussions taking place if we are going to decide whether this bill should be considered appropriate for those discussions? I think we should know. I think the Liberals would agree with us.
We have urged this government to present the arguments and the proposals. Evidently the Mexicans have had the privilege of being able to debate and discuss the free trade agreement. The Americans have had open discussions. Yet, we as parliamentarians have not even had the courtesy of having the proposals brought forward to the House. TLen the government has the gall to bring in a bill concerning taxation with Mexico and Finland.
I am not so sure, but we may agree that legislation is required. However, should we not know the ground rules we are playing with? Should we not know about the discussions taking place between this government, on behalf of Canada, and the Mexicans? I think we are entitled to that. If this government had a sense of fair play our members of Parliament could hear the discussions and examine the proposals it is trying to present to the Mexicans concerning free trade with Mexico, then

February 25, 1992
we would be in a much better position to understand the rationale of this piece of legislation before us.
This government cannot be trusted. The Canadian people do not trust this government. The New Democratic Party certainly does not trust this government. The Canadian people have very clearly shown their distrust in the polls, in which the Conservatives are at somewhere around 11 per cent as a result of the policies it is bringing in.
To bring a piece of legislation before this House with regard to taxation, especially with Mexico, at a time when we are in the middle of trying to bring some rationale to what this government is doing-and goodness' knows we have enough problems with the free trade agreement and its effects in Canada.
The government wants to introduce a bill that will set up a taxation agreement with Mexico and we do not even know what negotiations are taking place with the Mexican government concerning free trade. I do not think it does either. It is incompetent. It is showing its incompetence by bringing in a piece of legislation such as this before we even know the terms of the agreement and what we are going to be discussing with regard to free trade.

It ties directly to the free trade agreement with Mexico. We have not even seen the documentation or the proposals this government has put forward with regard to free trade with Mexico. It has a responsibility to bring those proposals before us so that we can see and scrutinize those documents.
Until the government does that, it cannot expect us, as parliamentarians, to be able to address the provisions of this bill. How could it?
